conclusion: Understanding the problem setup with a circular coil in a magnetic field and finding maximum power consumed by a resistor.
Details of the coil: 200 turns, area 1 m², resistance 10 Ω, connected to 50 Ω resistor, in a uniform magnetic field.
Magnetic field is changing over time, graph shows B changes with t.
Magnetic field increases linearly from 0.2 T at t=0 to 0.4 T at t=4 s.
Slope of B-t graph gives rate of change of B, which is dB/dt.
Faraday's law: ε = -N * (dΦ_B)/dt for induced emf due to changing magnetic field.
Magnetic flux Φ_B = B * A * cosθ, where θ = 0° since field is perpendicular.
Magnetic flux simplifies to Φ_B = B * A.
Induced emf is ε = -N * A * (dB/dt), considering magnitude only.
Calculate dB/dt: (0.4 T - 0.2 T)/(4 s - 0 s) = 0.05 T/s.
Plug values into emf formula: ε = 200 * 1 m² * 0.05 T/s = 10 V.
Total resistance in circuit is R + r = 50 Ω + 10 Ω = 60 Ω.
Current I through circuit is I = ε / (R + r) = 10 V / 60 Ω = 1/6 A.
Power consumed by resistor R is P_R = I² * R = (1/6)² * 50 = 50/36 W.
Consider if power can be increased; induced emf is constant as dB/dt is constant.
Since emf and current are constant, power is constant; maximum power is 50/36 W.
Re-evaluate if other factors like coil rotation affect power.
Figure B shows linear increase of magnetic field from 0.2 T to 0.4 T over 4 seconds.
